content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've never played Minecraft before, but when my wife picked up this game during it's free week, I decided I would check it out as well. It is absolutely FANTASTIC. I played it for about a day and a half before I decided to pay for it, and I don't even slightly regret the choice. It's still early access, and it occasionally shows, but this game shows an extremely high level of polish that i've not seen on some games that are even fully released. The bugs that i've come across are usually small, but pretty regularly re-creatable. However the depth and breadth of the game make them easy to overlook. My biggest problem is with the combat, honestly. It's almost always a battle of attrition, and if you survive, you tend to end up with low health. At that point it's almost better to just kill yourself somehow and run and get your things. Dying is basically a part of the game, so it's good that there's no REAL repercussions for doing so (other than having to go pick up the things in your bag). Some creatures are absurdly difficult, and dodging is almost a complete non-factor. You can, occasionally, find a good spot to dance a circle around a creature and not get hit, but it's inconsisitent.My 2nd largest issue is the durability of some items in the game compared to the amount of materials required to craft them. The mining cells in particular come to mind. There's one of two ways to solve this as far as I can see: Either make items with durability (like mining cells) last a lot longer, or make the odd materials to make them more readily available. I'm not saying I want my stone mining cell to last me through 18 hours of playtime, but I would like to be able to find 5 red flowers without running around for 20 minutes looking at every other tree I find.In spite of this, the game is immensely fun, and you can easily find yourself sucked into it. Digging into your mine deeper, crafting your house to look absurdly awesome, or just exploring the surprisingly vast environments, you'll find yourself readily wondering where the hours have gone. I'd definitely give this game a 9/10, because it's technically not even finished yet. You should definitely check it out.

content:
Posted: March 21
Early Access Review
								If you like MineCraft, you'll like Creativerse as well. It is more intuitive than MC, which is a huge bonus for new and/or younger players. There is plenty to do, and I have yet to feel that I was ever at a "dead end" trying to figure out what to do next. It's a good game, that gets upgraded to great game, due to the price. (Free!)You can purchase the "Pro" version for $20, but other than a flashlight and glider, there is nothing that Pro gives you that you can't get yourself in the Free version in game. The only other difference is on the Free version you are limited to one world at a time (Or you can play online on other people's servers). If you have Pro, you can have multiple worlds and more control over the settings for them.Personally. I feel that the $20 is a bit overpriced for what you get. (I get that the developers need, and deserve, to get paid.) If the Pro was $10, I would say jump on it in a heartbeat. Who knows, maybe it will go on sale someday!Graphics: Really nice. (Way better than minecraft. The world has a fun, and kinda "cartoony" feel to it.) Also, it runs great on my laptop, which means it should run great on tons of systems. 7/10Sound: Sounds a lot like MC. Which isn't a bad thing. 7/10Gameplay: Controls are good and responsive. Your character moves pretty predictably. Lots to see and do. Many different ways to play, depending on how you prefer. 8/10Re-Playability: Just like other open-world sandbox games. You might get bored after awhile, but wait a few weeks/months and you will get hooked again. (Repeat as needed.) 9/10Overall: 7.5 / 10 (Great)

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								What is Creativerse?Creativerse is an open world voxel/building game. The game is very similar to Minecraft, to the point that calling it a 'clone' would be fairly justified.After playing for a few hours recently I thourght I should share my my experiences and opinions.Pro's-Its 'FREE' to play.-Multiplayer works well and is easy to set up (Disregarding the many strange bugs currently present in multiplayer).-You can build giant phallic objects out of a number of different building materials.-Cute art styleCon's-VERY limited content, after playing through the game once start to finish you will know how to reach endgame in under an hour.-Once you have got to the 'end game' there is nothing to do beyond building something pretty.-Game is easy and unchangingly.-Combat and enemy AI is simplistic and boring.-Game is very much 'online only', there is no way to play offline without an internet connection.-MT's (Microtransactions) in an unfinished game that is lacking in content. It is possible to buy new block recipes from the ingame store for real money, however some of these are available in game as rare drops from monsters.R33 UpdateThe recent R33 update has added something akin to minecraft's redstone to the game, however from my experiences so far there is very little to do with it, sure, you can make a door/pressure plate system and some light switches, then what?Whereas in minecraft you can use redstone to create wonderfully complex contraptions with actual function, the 'machines' in this game are more of an after thourght.PRO accountsI don't even... What?Another part of the R33 update is the addition of pro accounts, this is in my opinon the worst thing they could have possibily done to this game and is the reason I will not be playing this game any further.So what diffrenace does a PRO account make?-PRO players get a flashlight and a glider (thats right, you can fly in this game! but only if you pay £19.99)-Free players are now limited to creating only one world with VERY limited options compared to those with PRO.Review SummaryI cannot in good faith bring myself to recommend this game to anyone over the age of 5, there is simply not enough content or enough to do to keep a person entertained. What content is present is very short lived and easy to complete.The recent update to add machines is a step in the right direction however still needs 'more'. I am painfully aware that games dont develop themselves and servers cost money, however I cannot support the developers in thier choice. This has created a clear division between players, how can a company that claims they dont want to add 'pay to play or pay to win' elements justifiy paid players being able to fly and non-paid not?

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								For the 6 hours I played, non-stop mind you, I have to give this game a lot of credit. A friend bought this for me after telling me about it and I was a bit iffy on the idea of another sandbox game similar to Minecraft. But, there is a lot of differnces between the two games.The structure of the game itself gives a whole new feel if you are use to playing Minecraft. It's not as easy as chop some wood, mine some stone, then you're good to go. There is a lot of depth to just the crafting alone. While it is still fairly easy to find all the resources you need, you need a lot of them. Even after you collect them, you might need to use some tools to break it down into a different matterial. (For example, breaking vines down into twine.) Yes, you have wait times on crafting stuff. While it isn't too terribly bad, the times do get a bit longer as you start using more advanced materials such as Obsidian, Iron, and Diamonds. But in my opinion, it adds more to the game because now you have to wait 5 minutes to advance and in that time, you could go out and collect more resources or even go spelunking.The creatures in the game is definitely unique. While some do remind me of creatures from Jak and Daxter (the night Pigsy's and night Leafi's), they still have a unique vibe to them. And they of course vary in difficulty. While a few of them have unique skills such as blinding you for a short time or spinning to do a lot of damage, there isn't a lot to worry about as long as you keep some distance.Also, there is furniture. And to be honest, it actually looks pretty nice. There is also a lot of ways to customize and build your own house and make it stand out from your friends. You have different types of carpet, walls, and even slanted roof planks you can craft. You even have different colored lamps. You could use them like my friend does and make each room different colors. Though the blue sometimes confuses me because I never know if it is dark out or not. But it still looks really nice. Much like a room with a bunch of black lights.To add on to the crafting idea to the game, you do not start off with being able to craft everything in the game. You have to work your way up and find the recipes. While some of them are scattered in chests around the world, you usually unlock new ones after you craft something else. Like weapons for instance. After you craft a wood sword, you unlock the crafting recipe for a stone sword. Which means you have to work to find better things, meaning you actually have a goal to work towards.While there is still some bugs in the game with it being early access, it still runs fairly smooth and it's easy to play with friends. No port forwarding or setting up custom servers. Simply create a world and set a password so your friends can join up. Even when you are offline, they can still join the world and continue which to me, is pretty awesome. I would gladly recommend this game to anyone who likes Minecraft or sandbox games in general. And I think if you actually take some time with this game, you'll find there is a lot of possibilites with it.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								     I went into this not sure if I was going to like the game, but willing to give it a little bit of time to see for myself.  After the first few hours of playtime, I realised that I was hooked.  My family and I have always loved playing minecraft together and this is everything we loved about that game and then some.  We can create, we can fight, we can BLOW THINGS UP!  It allows each of us to play in our own style.  The amazing part is that this is still being tweaked and improved upon to add even more incredible things.  There are only two things that I can see on the negative side so far and those are:         1. There is no offline gameplay         2.  Characters are not modable (but you do get  a choice between being a boy or a girl)     The fact that these are the only things that I and my family can find that are negative, says a lot.  In the future, these things could also change.  We will be playing this game for a long time to come so hopefully we will see it come about.  I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone!

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Creativerse effectively takes everything I didn't like about Minecraft and fixes it. The inventory is better, the crafting is better, containers are handled better, there's a greater variety of enemies. Even things like the look of the characters and environment. Multiplayer is very easy to do, and you can make your world public or put on a password so only your friends can join.Don't let the "pro" status or microtransactions turn you off. The benefits are primarily cosmetic or simply a shortcut to things you could readily gain in-game, and you still get for free more than you would get for paying for Minecraft.

Early Access Review
								I downloaded this game thinking it would most likely be mediocre to bad. I have played minecraft a little and thought to give this game a shot. It's great! Especially for a free game. The whole world, mechanics, music, crafting... it's all done so much better than minecraft. I feel peaceful when I play. The instructions are clear as to what you need to do in order to build xyz. The physics is nice as well. It has that sort of.. floaty unreal/quake feel. I even tried strafe jumping and it almost worked haha.If someone is looking for a cute game (that is also safe for kids) to pass the time and relieve stress, I would recommend this!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well this is gonna be a first impression view on the game. And I'm gonna make 3 categories beginning, mid-game and present.Beginning - I started playing this game with a friend a long time ago (around April) but we lost interest after we found out about the system of mining (The extractors) they took way too much time to extract essential stuff so we lost interest. Later on (couple months ahead) we decided to give it another go because we were bored we had nothing to play yada yada. My friend started to enjoy the game meanwhile I kinda found it still boring and just not suitable for me so I quitted for like 1 day. Mid-game - My friend finally convinced me to get back in the game, she built a house, showed me this and that and actually how fun this game is so I caught some interest in the game so we played together. Helped her creating the house (btw building thing for houses and such is amazing) I got hypnotized by this game and its mechanics even though I hated it at first. We played finally finished the house yada yada. Later on we found something weird ? I mean we built a pool and when she played and I was away the pool got bugged out and got all destroyed over night while she was asleep ? Also random holes in the ground appeared, might have been some bug because she restarted the game and it worked afterwards. Present - We found out about more crafting materials, gear, blocks to build with and we got really into it. To be honest I kinda feel that the game is way too easy ? In terms of finding resources and such. I don't really have anything else to say.. moving on.PROS & CONS:PROS: -Amazing game if you have a good friend to play it with            -Crafting and imagination of building stuff, realistic outlook of the houses you build is amazing as well           -Gearing up in the game seems quite fast in the later gear (at the beginning the game is quite slow)           -I found it fun and kept me intrigued even to this very momentCONS: -Feels like its quite a glidy game and it still needs some updates in terms of movement and smoothnes            -Even though I have a quite decent PC it still drops frames for me and has couple lag spikes for some reason (might be some optimization problems)            -Don't play it alone you'll get really bored (that applies for me)            -Combat is not as accurate.. mobs can still hit you from 10m away and sometimes you can't even hit them (sword      literally goes trough them)            -AI.. Ok the AI is legitimately stupid. Mobs tend not to attack if you're one block higher than them (doesn't happen all the time)            -This game ♥♥♥♥s the physics.

content:
Posted: April 17
Early Access Review
								This game is great, don't be fooled by inadequate reviewers, this game has a lot to offer, if you've played minecraft and have been craving a new open world sandbox experience then this game is fantastic, and is worth the small $20 price tag.From what I've seen in past reviews, most people tend to complain that this game is "too much like Minecraft" and that it's ridiculous to make you have to pay to use certain features, which in some aspects is completely fair, but let's not forget that Minecraft itself has a $25 price tag, sure that comes with more content, but that game has been around several years longer than this game, it really personally triggers me when I hear people say that "the developers ****ed up by making you have to pay to use certain features" ('cause it would totally be fair to make this game 100% free and allow the developers to earn literally nothing for the years of work they put in... genius) let us not forget that Minecraft's "free" version you couldn't even create 1 world, you'd have a creative sandbox and that was it, nothing was saved, the player got nothing but a taste, at least these developers allow people to play their game and decide whether or not to purchase it..Now let's get down to gameplay itself;Gameplay felt great in terms of player feedback as far as menu's and some aspects of combat, some issues I'd noticed when playing was not having a far enough reach with your attacks (most of the time you'd end up getting hit at around the same time that you can actually reach the creature) this was a bit of disappointing but I'm not going to say that it ruined the game. Content wise this game has around 20 - 30 hours worth of content to explore, items to collect and creatures to meet, the blueprint system was quite nice in some regards too! Something that disappointed me though was the method of collecting certain minerals was just a pain, having to craft an extractor everytime that you wanted to harvest an ore was an absolute pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Mainly just because the extractors themselves are quite costly to craft early game which makes an unnecessarily long start.The crafting system was easy to understand and I liked how you had to learn to craft a previous version of an item before you craft the next tier, for example; diamond sword required you to have crafted an iron sword previously to be able to unlock the recipe for the diamond sword. I also loved the waypoint system where you could teleport to saved waypoints at any time by pressing 't'.Overall this game is a lot of fun with friends or by yourself, the $20 pricetag is justified with the amount of content, but if you're looking to play this game once, download the free version and get almost the exact same experience! Crafting was nice and easy to understand  but mining and some combat was a little lackluster.In conclusion, give this game a go, you may be surprised! And since this game is in early access, you can watch this game and community grow with only more exciting content to come!

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								What drew me into this game is it's basically a more intricate minecraft.In Creativerse the weaker creations have to be crafted before you can create stronger creations (like stone stairs have to be crafted before you have the option to craft diamond stairs). Creativerse is more of a game I would play if I just wanted to burn time. It does glitch here and there. At times I can't see any of the world around me but I can see through it and then it loads in. I do love that when I die all my stuff is saved in a vase that only I can get to it when I spawn back in. The blueprints for structers are a wonderful touch and I do wish they had those in minecraft too but sadly that's not the case.

								GRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRREAT!Addictivley fun with infinate possibility.I was hesitant at first to get this game.  My initial reaction was "O wow another Minecraft rip-off" oh how I was wrong!Yes, it is a voxel based game.  Yes it is sandbox.  Yes it is about survival and crafting. My friends and I who have been playing MC FOREVER got this game a couple days ago and instantly liked it more than MC.  8.5/10

Early Access Review
								I downloaded this game thinking it would most likely be mediocre to bad. I have played minecraft a little and thought to give this game a shot. It's great! Especially for a free game. The whole world, mechanics, music, crafting... it's all done so much better than minecraft. I feel peaceful when I play. The instructions are clear as to what you need to do in order to build xyz. The physics is nice as well. It has that sort of.. floaty unreal/quake feel. I even tried strafe jumping and it almost worked haha.If someone is looking for a cute game (that is also safe for kids) to pass the time and relieve stress, I would recommend this!

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								I only have a few hours into the game thus far, but already it has impressed me. There will be a lot of people compare this to Minecraft, and thats fine, cause when it comes down to it, its the exact same principle, only done much better with already far more building materials. And its still being added to, hence that its still in Early Access. My only problem so far is the games tends to have severe FPS drops and my machine is no slouch. Though I've read that many are seeing this as well. But hey, its still in development, so I can forgive for that. If you played Minecraft, or games like it, and you enjoyed them, then give this a go. Heck, even if you never played a game like this before, give it a go. I mean, what do have to lose, its free!I will update this after I've played the game a bit more and after a couple more updates to the game.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I played Minecraft for a long time, and during that time, I gave up playing on servers due to bugs, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ players, and plugins that make it generally not fun(donate $5.00 to be able to place water OKAY). On top of that, the only way I could ever have fun was by downloading mods which took way too long and sometimes they didn't even work.Creativerse is different, it still has the same feel from when I first played minecraft and then some. The enemies are strange and unique. The landscape is blocky and still looks gorgeous. The music is interesting to listen to. And, I don't have to constantly worry about some green, walking human sized phallus walking over to me and blowing my house to kingdom come! It's still a bit glitchy, but it's early access. What can you do?

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review as of 20 hours of gameplay. The game is quite fun and addicting. I like the fact that you have to unlock recipes and there's different types of "mobs".I have ran into a few glitches/bugs in the game. Such as getting launched into the air falling to my death. I really like the gameplay. It's like minecraft, but more visually stimulating. I love the exploration, and large biomes. I can't really judge the game with only 20 hours of gametime. So I'll updating a better pros/cons list after i play for 100 hours or more. Played during the free weekend event, ended up buying it before the trial ended. Worth the $9.99 it was. I hope this game goes as far as Minecraft did. It has so much potential. :D

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								Keep in mind that I only have a few hours into the game as I'm writing this, and that the game is in Early Access.+ Fluent Combat(compared to many other voxel games)+ Graphics are gorgeous(compared to many other voxel games)+ Good Soundtrack+ Nice Tiering system, gives the feeling you are actually progressing+ Lots and LOTS of stuff to play around with(and it seems there is much more to come)+ Seems there is a lot to do and discover- Crafting items is smashed all over the place(First you need to craft something in your Q menu, then you have to use machine A to craft piece B, and then you have to combine it with Piece C that has been created in machine X... you get my point. It's rather overwhelming, and quite time consuming)- Interface needs improvement(As for now, you have to browse huge lists just to find that one thing you want to make. And the further you go, the bigger the lists become. Seriously needs a few QoL improvements there)- Monster AI is quite derpy, sometimes ignoring people completely- Once you got your basic set, the game isn't very challenging anymore(unlike items, it doesn't feel there are different many tiers of monsters out there(... yet?))- Standard occasional bugs(no major crashing yet, just a few silly bugs like being stuck in the ceiling after jumping on the bed x.x)(+ you can jump on the bed)- FPS drops a little when venturing underground(Nothing major, but slower comps might notice it)As it is now, It's the typical Early Access game. It's playable, it's enjoyable, and it has great potential. There has been a lot of thought put into the game, and I appreciate it. The game isn't there yet, hence the EA status. It's up to the devs whether this game will become a master piece, or another could-have-been-awesome.I will update my review if it turns out to be the latter, but until then, download and give it a try!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Much better than Minecraft, for creative discovery, for the following reasons.  Crafting guides you towards what you need (no more having to look it up elsewhere online), and requires more appropriate resources (you cut a wood block into multiple slabs or rods instead of building a stick out of multiple wood blocks, and two sticks for a handle).  The scenery is generated with impressive variety, trees of various kinds with branches, vines, flowers, etc.  There are different terrains to find various items that change the scenery quite a bit.  Mining is more logical with depth being important for what you're looking for.  Creative play is easier to setup without bouncing between "survival" and "god-mode creative" modes, it's a good balance where you have to work, but not struggle.  Maps are shared online, so I don't have to be online to share a world with my son.  Not paying $27 times two is a big bonus as well, and blueprints are fairly enjoyable to work together on similar to a co-op resource gathering 3D puzzle board.I recommend this for anybody who wants to get into Minecraft creative exploration style play with their friends or family, but doesn't want to put up with all the difficulty of setup, wants to save some money, or just wants more options and a more enjoyable time.  It is plenty fun with the Free version, I'll likely upgrade to the Pro once my son masters the game a bit more.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								First off, let's not beat around the bush here. Creativerse can easily be mistaken for just another Minecraft clone. Just taking a single glance at this game can give it that impression. And I can understand that first-glance impression to a certain degree. If you are expecting a game that is radically different from Minecraft, you are quite frankly looking in the wrong place.That said though, I enjoy Creativerse quite a bit more than I enjoy Minecraft. The thing with Creativerse is that it aims to be a bigger and better Minecraft, and I personally think that they are doing pretty good at that for now. There are enough differences and improvements between the two games that I can say Creativerse is well worth a try if you have either played Minecraft already or if you just couldn't bring yourself to play Minecraft but wanted a similar(/better) game. First off, I honestly believe Creativerse is clearer and easier to get into than Minecraft is. If only just for the reason that in Creativerse you can see what you can craft and that there are blueprints available that let you know what you need to craft it in the first place. Minecraft just throws you in the deep end and just says 'I dunno, you go figure it out' without any notion of a hint or general direction. And while Creativerse does something similair, it at least does so with a better UI and a little bit of help.Secondly are the much better graphics. Minecraft is notorious for just being a bunch of badly textured blocks. Creativerse is still designed around blocks as well, but at least in Creativerse they look much nicer and better designed. The biggest con I can think of, and one I think needs to be mentioned, is that this game is entirely focused on being online. If the servers (or your internet connection) decide to go AWOL, then that's it, no more Creativerse for you until the connection is restored.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well this is gonna be a first impression view on the game. And I'm gonna make 3 categories beginning, mid-game and present.Beginning - I started playing this game with a friend a long time ago (around April) but we lost interest after we found out about the system of mining (The extractors) they took way too much time to extract essential stuff so we lost interest. Later on (couple months ahead) we decided to give it another go because we were bored we had nothing to play yada yada. My friend started to enjoy the game meanwhile I kinda found it still boring and just not suitable for me so I quitted for like 1 day. Mid-game - My friend finally convinced me to get back in the game, she built a house, showed me this and that and actually how fun this game is so I caught some interest in the game so we played together. Helped her creating the house (btw building thing for houses and such is amazing) I got hypnotized by this game and its mechanics even though I hated it at first. We played finally finished the house yada yada. Later on we found something weird ? I mean we built a pool and when she played and I was away the pool got bugged out and got all destroyed over night while she was asleep ? Also random holes in the ground appeared, might have been some bug because she restarted the game and it worked afterwards. Present - We found out about more crafting materials, gear, blocks to build with and we got really into it. To be honest I kinda feel that the game is way too easy ? In terms of finding resources and such. I don't really have anything else to say.. moving on.PROS & CONS:PROS: -Amazing game if you have a good friend to play it with            -Crafting and imagination of building stuff, realistic outlook of the houses you build is amazing as well           -Gearing up in the game seems quite fast in the later gear (at the beginning the game is quite slow)           -I found it fun and kept me intrigued even to this very momentCONS: -Feels like its quite a glidy game and it still needs some updates in terms of movement and smoothnes            -Even though I have a quite decent PC it still drops frames for me and has couple lag spikes for some reason (might be some optimization problems)            -Don't play it alone you'll get really bored (that applies for me)            -Combat is not as accurate.. mobs can still hit you from 10m away and sometimes you can't even hit them (sword      literally goes trough them)            -AI.. Ok the AI is legitimately stupid. Mobs tend not to attack if you're one block higher than them (doesn't happen all the time)            -This game ♥♥♥♥s the physics.

								Obviously a minecraft clone. Has some minor glitches here and there, nothing severe. It's also for free, you can purchase some cosmetic blocks or blue-prints for bigger structures (which you really don't need if you prefer to design your home by yourself).

								Much better than Minecraft, for creative discovery, for the following reasons.  Crafting guides you towards what you need (no more having to look it up elsewhere online), and requires more appropriate resources (you cut a wood block into multiple slabs or rods instead of building a stick out of multiple wood blocks, and two sticks for a handle).  The scenery is generated with impressive variety, trees of various kinds with branches, vines, flowers, etc.  There are different terrains to find various items that change the scenery quite a bit.  Mining is more logical with depth being important for what you're looking for.  Creative play is easier to setup without bouncing between "survival" and "god-mode creative" modes, it's a good balance where you have to work, but not struggle.  Maps are shared online, so I don't have to be online to share a world with my son.  Not paying $27 times two is a big bonus as well, and blueprints are fairly enjoyable to work together on similar to a co-op resource gathering 3D puzzle board.I recommend this for anybody who wants to get into Minecraft creative exploration style play with their friends or family, but doesn't want to put up with all the difficulty of setup, wants to save some money, or just wants more options and a more enjoyable time.  It is plenty fun with the Free version, I'll likely upgrade to the Pro once my son masters the game a bit more.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been looking for an open-world, exploration, crafting, 3D, creative sandbox game for a while, and this is the one that finally grabbed me instantly. Graphics are cute and funny and polished (without being too cute), biomes are varied and beautiful, and the world is big enough for a long time of playing. I like spending hours just running around gathering stuff, or exploring an area (usually a cave) where I haven't been before; you can do that here. If you're rather the more active sort and want to build and build and build, you can do that too: lots of blocks available. You can play alone, with friends, with strangers, and it's all easy to do, no offline mode though. The game is still in early access and the developers have been active and busy, there are frequent updates and they do listen to feedback -- so it can only get better! Personally I would have preferred the game not to go F2P, but it was planned from the beginning and I think it can work (it's not pay-to-win in any way, items for purchase are purely cosmetic).My favourite thing? All the little descriptions for every item in the game.I bought the game before it went F2P and haven't regretted it; it's free now, so you have no excuse: try it out and see if it grabs you the way it grabbed me!

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								     I enjoyed this game a lot, and still do, but you have to understand that when you play this game for free, you wont have all the options you used to. People now a days are getting really used to things just being handed to them, but as a game developer, you need money to keep the lights on. Now, this game is easily comaprable to Minecraft (which costs $26.95 for PC) but to have pretty much all the bells and whistles for this game its just $20. So now you can oly have 1 world if you just do this for free, and you are missing many options. I find you can still progress to end game items at a relatively good speed, and you can still build/claim plots as you did before (with a few very minor options lost). You can also only play on normal difficulty.. Considering the options, its still pretty fun to play it for free, and you can put a little extra for extra plots. A good loop around is to have a second steam account to make a multiplayer world as well.     All that said, lets compaire it to Minecraft a little in free to play sense. Minecraft on PC only lets you play for 10 in game days before you are cut off from your world... granted you have full access. Minecraft for consoles only offers you the ability to play in the tutorial... which is okay, but is lacking in sooo many ways.. long story short, the devs could just call the free to play version, a demo perhaps, then maybe people will stop crying about the features... because compared to minecrafts Demo, this is definately way better than the minecraft Demo.     Now on to pro, the features arent a ton, but they feel pretty worth it. Im definately not going into this with any salt towards the game at all, as it is a pretty great game with, or without pro. Now, pro is only $20 and offers nearly the full game, with the exception to have a few purchaseable added graphic block.. without them, the game still offers a pretty large number of options for creation. I see all these things as a way for people to support the devs. $20 gets you the game for the cost of 4 packs of cigarettes, or not much else you toss extra money into for minor temporary indulgence you buy... What this means is, if you play with friends a lot, you can make many worlds that they may join and play on. You also support their continued work on the game. It deos not feel pay to win, and definately not over priced. Back in the day, many games werent free to play, and many times you could buy them, only to find they dont work on your machine, or they are buggy and not worth the cost, or just plain garbage. Some games were returnable, but many with cd keys for pc were not... Keep that in mind.     This game is not for everyone, but it is worth trying. If you enjoy blocky survival sandbox games, this game is worth trying out. It looks really nice for its genre, and gameplay is pretty interesting as well. I have put thousands of hours into Minecraft, but play Minecraft and many games like it a lot less now, but can say i still enjoy them. This game is definately a nice alternative to minecraft, but not a replacement. What i would like to see in this, so it may be more equal to minecraft, is maybe a modable pro version; one that is easily modable, with offline, and online mode... Perhaps for online keep the modding to personal servers, run on their own server computer, or pc, which is obviously kept easily modable. Should they make it easy to have a large modding comunity, I could definately see this wrecking minecraft, especially with Minecrafts loss of Bukkit.

content:
Posted: January 2
Early Access Review
								It's insane how good this game is, considering you can play it for free. Game is fun, good-looking and run smoothly - try it for yourself ;)At 2017-01-03 (written by complete newbie): Right off the bat you start within your own world with 40 inventory spaces and basic mining tool. LMB gather stuff, RMB place/use selected (item under highlighted 1-2-3... hotspot). Q to craft, E for inventory, TAB to quick swap weapon/mining. At night hostile mobs spawns at surface, underground you can find them all day. It's good to know that to gather some resources you have to place one-time-use items on them and wait. Placing torches reduces/prevents enemies from spawning. Crafting buildings and containers can be picked up and placed (if there are no items being stored/processed within them). Graphics are good. Jumping is kind of annoying but expected in this kind of game. There is insane amount of things you can craft and place ^_^

content:
Posted: April 17
Early Access Review
								This game is great, don't be fooled by inadequate reviewers, this game has a lot to offer, if you've played minecraft and have been craving a new open world sandbox experience then this game is fantastic, and is worth the small $20 price tag.From what I've seen in past reviews, most people tend to complain that this game is "too much like Minecraft" and that it's ridiculous to make you have to pay to use certain features, which in some aspects is completely fair, but let's not forget that Minecraft itself has a $25 price tag, sure that comes with more content, but that game has been around several years longer than this game, it really personally triggers me when I hear people say that "the developers ****ed up by making you have to pay to use certain features" ('cause it would totally be fair to make this game 100% free and allow the developers to earn literally nothing for the years of work they put in... genius) let us not forget that Minecraft's "free" version you couldn't even create 1 world, you'd have a creative sandbox and that was it, nothing was saved, the player got nothing but a taste, at least these developers allow people to play their game and decide whether or not to purchase it..Now let's get down to gameplay itself;Gameplay felt great in terms of player feedback as far as menu's and some aspects of combat, some issues I'd noticed when playing was not having a far enough reach with your attacks (most of the time you'd end up getting hit at around the same time that you can actually reach the creature) this was a bit of disappointing but I'm not going to say that it ruined the game. Content wise this game has around 20 - 30 hours worth of content to explore, items to collect and creatures to meet, the blueprint system was quite nice in some regards too! Something that disappointed me though was the method of collecting certain minerals was just a pain, having to craft an extractor everytime that you wanted to harvest an ore was an absolute pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Mainly just because the extractors themselves are quite costly to craft early game which makes an unnecessarily long start.The crafting system was easy to understand and I liked how you had to learn to craft a previous version of an item before you craft the next tier, for example; diamond sword required you to have crafted an iron sword previously to be able to unlock the recipe for the diamond sword. I also loved the waypoint system where you could teleport to saved waypoints at any time by pressing 't'.Overall this game is a lot of fun with friends or by yourself, the $20 pricetag is justified with the amount of content, but if you're looking to play this game once, download the free version and get almost the exact same experience! Crafting was nice and easy to understand  but mining and some combat was a little lackluster.In conclusion, give this game a go, you may be surprised! And since this game is in early access, you can watch this game and community grow with only more exciting content to come!

content:
Posted: March 29
Early Access Review
								I've played this game for 21.5 out of the past 48 hours. Firstly, this game features an amazingly smooth and rewarding crafting system. It's simple and to the point! No complex blueprints and all that mess. Even with blueprints, it shows you what you need, and where you need it. Too easy! The combat in Creativerse is actually quite solid for a sandbox builder. You can craft different tiers of swords; as well as explosives and stun bombs. The soundtrack for this game is simply awesome. It makes some of the most tedious and difficult tasks less frustrating. It's calming and exciting at the perfect times. I LOVE mining in this game. When you get down there and start finding chests, Obsidian Ore, Coal, etc, it's just such an awesome feeling. You can set up your own area down there and get a TON of resources. Lastly, I have to mention the pets. You can tame (if you're slick about it) just about any enemy in Creativerse. You can also find things such as party hats and other accessories in chests and equip them to your pet. Overall, this game is so much fun. It's free and not another pay-to-win. Get in there and create!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
Early Access Review
								This game is great, don't be fooled by inadequate reviewers, this game has a lot to offer, if you've played minecraft and have been craving a new open world sandbox experience then this game is fantastic, and is worth the small $20 price tag.From what I've seen in past reviews, most people tend to complain that this game is "too much like Minecraft" and that it's ridiculous to make you have to pay to use certain features, which in some aspects is completely fair, but let's not forget that Minecraft itself has a $25 price tag, sure that comes with more content, but that game has been around several years longer than this game, it really personally triggers me when I hear people say that "the developers ****ed up by making you have to pay to use certain features" ('cause it would totally be fair to make this game 100% free and allow the developers to earn literally nothing for the years of work they put in... genius) let us not forget that Minecraft's "free" version you couldn't even create 1 world, you'd have a creative sandbox and that was it, nothing was saved, the player got nothing but a taste, at least these developers allow people to play their game and decide whether or not to purchase it..Now let's get down to gameplay itself;Gameplay felt great in terms of player feedback as far as menu's and some aspects of combat, some issues I'd noticed when playing was not having a far enough reach with your attacks (most of the time you'd end up getting hit at around the same time that you can actually reach the creature) this was a bit of disappointing but I'm not going to say that it ruined the game. Content wise this game has around 20 - 30 hours worth of content to explore, items to collect and creatures to meet, the blueprint system was quite nice in some regards too! Something that disappointed me though was the method of collecting certain minerals was just a pain, having to craft an extractor everytime that you wanted to harvest an ore was an absolute pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Mainly just because the extractors themselves are quite costly to craft early game which makes an unnecessarily long start.The crafting system was easy to understand and I liked how you had to learn to craft a previous version of an item before you craft the next tier, for example; diamond sword required you to have crafted an iron sword previously to be able to unlock the recipe for the diamond sword. I also loved the waypoint system where you could teleport to saved waypoints at any time by pressing 't'.Overall this game is a lot of fun with friends or by yourself, the $20 pricetag is justified with the amount of content, but if you're looking to play this game once, download the free version and get almost the exact same experience! Crafting was nice and easy to understand  but mining and some combat was a little lackluster.In conclusion, give this game a go, you may be surprised! And since this game is in early access, you can watch this game and community grow with only more exciting content to come!

Early Access Review
								What drew me into this game is it's basically a more intricate minecraft.In Creativerse the weaker creations have to be crafted before you can create stronger creations (like stone stairs have to be crafted before you have the option to craft diamond stairs). Creativerse is more of a game I would play if I just wanted to burn time. It does glitch here and there. At times I can't see any of the world around me but I can see through it and then it loads in. I do love that when I die all my stuff is saved in a vase that only I can get to it when I spawn back in. The blueprints for structers are a wonderful touch and I do wish they had those in minecraft too but sadly that's not the case.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Good game, recommended if you are looking for a nice ran. gen. world sandbox game to play. Great with friends because you can abuse the free teleporters a lot. You'll enjoy this game a lot more if you don't compare it to Minecraft while playing it. Pros: refreshing and new enemies, unique items, excellent horizontal progression (instead of dumpster diving down to the strongest tier right off the bat). Cons: crappy combat, few weapons, movement feels really bubbly (could be a pro for some?), mining could be faster, healing requires a bit of a grind (bloodborne tier)Basically what Minecraft should have been, what Cube World will hopefully be, and what Terraria does in but in 3D.

content:
Posted: January 23
Early Access Review
								This game is actually far better than it looks. My friend and I were looking for ♥♥♥♥♥♥ free games and stumbled upon this gem. We had a good laugh and decided to download it. When we got into the game, we initially were shocked by how much of a Minecraft clone it was (and how hunky it looked). But as we started playing more, it grew on us. After a while I looked at the clock and realised we'd been playing for about 3 hours.This game looks gross at a glance, but it's actually quite charming. It has plenty of things that I've lwys wanted out of Minecraft, and it's completely free. That being said, it has a few bugs, and the movement is quite floaty. But those can all be overlooked if you have a friend to play with.So if you're looking for a bit of good fun for free with a friend, I absolutly reccomend Creativerse.69/420 heh heh heh

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								I absolutely adore this game, it's a little harder to play than Minecraft (okay a lot harder) but since Pro has come about I can set the Mobs to "peaceful" and don't have to worry about being attacked every five seconds. People say it's like Minecraft but only a little bit, the graphics are way better and it's more challenging and fun :) I like taming the bad Mobs and making them food so they give me things in return!I think my only gripe is that the mining cells eventually break and you have to craft a whole new one, it's very tedious but other than that (and nasty people coming to blow up your whole world - which is fixed by Pro because you can set it to No Explosives allowed but that means harder to mine things without TNT) All in all - I give this game two thumbs up!!

It feels more alive, it's beautiful, and the multiplayer is great! The multiplayer is the biggest thing that makes me recommend this game. I can have my own server to play with friends without having to port forward or add mods and what not. It's just that easy! And it's early access, which means there's even more to come. If I have any complaints they're far and few between and not crazy important. I recommend this, give it a try!

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2
Early Access Review
								Hey there, possible player!Well, now that the game is free, you shouldn't need too much convincing to at least try it. I bought this when it first came out at the 20 dollars and I don't regret it in the least. A lotta folks will compare this to minecraft, and of course you could, but this game truly stands on its own.For one, it's way effing prettier than Minecraft, and while still a bit lacking, the character customization is much more in-depth. Two, the building and crafting system is quite immersive and fun. You can build more depending on what you've already discovered and created so you have to work your way up to the good stuff, which I find pretty darn neat. Gives the game a longer play-life. The exploration and fighting system are also pretty damn good. No mods needed for a comprehensive compass and map system, and most blocks are VERY distiguishable. If you're looking for a huge challenge as far as monsters go, there isn't much of that, but I find that to be a good thing that way more casual players can get the good stuff too, with hard work. Instead of a nether, there is something called the corruption layer, and there's all sorts of fun and spooky stuff down there! So that is probably the biggest challenge of the game so far that I'm aware of.They also have a system called Taming, where you can make pretty much any mob in the game a pet! You can even dress them up in little hats and bows. They produce mob-specific mats for you. All in all, if you want a nice relaxing game with a great building, exploration, fighting, inventory, and crafting system, play this.

content:
Posted: April 11
Early Access Review
								[4/5] The terrain graphics are quiet decent if set to max setting.[2/5] Player character graphics & their animation really need to be improved / re-created.[5/5] Building can be very creative with many variants of blocks/items & the mighty [R]otate tool.[4/5] Combat is definetly a good spot in the game, comparing to games likes Minecraft. However it                     could use more variety of weapons; axes, spears,  & expensive laser guns.[5/5] Tinkering & Farming, its definetly well made.[5/5] Developers earn money by having players purchase the pro version of the game, however the pro version isn't neceserally pay to win. Which is great, of course and i hope it stays that way.SuggestionsPlease finish the /Quests update... xDGuilds! Add guilds that are bound to worlds. It disables combat against guild mates (If set, otherwise by default world setting)Trading: Vending Machines / Custom npcs (Where players can create their custom npc/robots & set them a 'job'. Examples; Guard,  Merchant, Questmaster, Guildmaster (Guild quests, etc), & a banker which would be costly to unlock but could allow upgading vaults. Finally, auction house employee. If a player decides to sell an item, they can talk to the auctioneer and set an item for sale. All items for sale at the auction house would be display in a list, & players could bid with a set currency. Example; Obsidian/Coal/Diamonds/Lumite (Or if the devs plan to add a currency item) Side noteBought pro after a 100 hours of normal gameplay, can't wait to see the future updates. Keep them coming! Also, who's developing Creativerse? An indie studio?

content:
Posted: April 11
Early Access Review
								Well, I guess I've played long enough to comment on it now.Creativerse helped my family find an activity we could do together. It began as just my wife playing, then my 7 year-old began playing too. And then I had to look into this thing they were both enjoying so much. And yeah, suddenly I have 1000 hours in this *cough* casual little game.Us three, we play for different reasons. My wife loves to build. My daughter loves to explore. And I love the feeling of survival, of combat in the first 50 hours of any world. They prefer to stick to one world, but I admit I like to bounce around, see who I meet and what sort of fun they've created for themselves in other worlds. Creativerse really offers many ways to play, and even more now with the launch of user-created Adventures. You are not stuck in any one routine.The art style just works. It is simple and pleasing, without feeling like you've fallen through a wormhole to 1990. The staff and developers will actually communicate with you (and even answer emails!). A plethora of great Youtubers have made videos to give you clarity over features, or inspiration for things to try. A Pro "upgrade" is currently available if you wanna toss a few bucks at the developers, and the perks are worth it in my opinion.So, yeah. Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								It had been nearly 24 months since I wrote my initial review of this game. I need to update this especially with the kerfluffle that occured in the R33 update. There are other reviews that can talk about the depth of this game and how it compares to say a Minecraft game. But I want to address the reviews. If you're seeing some negative reviews trending to the top due to R33, then keep reading because I feel those bad reviews are dishonest and I'd like to give a more even handed review.So basically, alot of the man children and 14 year olds are mad because the devs introduced several new outstanding features. This includes the ability to use a glider to fly around the world. Weeeeee! You can customize your own world server. And other smaller enhancements such as a flashlight and increased inventory storage. However, in order to have this, you must pay for Creativerse Pro for $20. But they are being generous and giving Pro to early access backers or anyone who bought anything through the store. However, there is one downside. They are also limiting free players from only owning 1 world rather than owning multiple worlds, as had existed prior to R33.  I can see why some are mad at Playful for limiting ownership of worlds to 1 per free player whereas before you could own unlimited worlds. All of these worlds take up alot of server space which the devs must pay for. And there are few reasons anyone needs to own this many worlds to begin with. Each world is huge unto itself and can accomdate a couple thousand players easily. So outside of that, the game is in no way affected and the quality continues to get better. And I'll bet you anything those people complaining will still keep playing.Claims such as this being pay to win and other silly giberish are just that; gibberish. Apparently all the freeloaders think a 15 man company should starve to death and not be able to pay their rent by simply giving everything away for free. Gasp. The nerve of this company!In fact, with the introduction of basic machinery and wiring in R33, I expect to see the devs introduce more advanced machinery and functionality. Perhaps think Scrap Mechanics but for voxel based building? Just guessing and hoping.I had nearly 100 hours into this game before stopping to play for 9 months. But these new features along with everything else they added in between has pushed me to start playing again with new excitement.TLDR: Some of the playerbase are too cheap to pay $20 and using the tired P2W meme as their way to spite Playful.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wouldn't recommend it just yet, because I haven't been able to "Connect to a Server," with a block eternally spinning in front of my face as the "Connecting to Server" window shows no signs of any servers being connected too, which is very frustrating considering I did pay $20 for it. The in-game store to cut out waiting for items to be crafted is kind of a bad idea considering it's basically paying out of impatience and so many "pay-to-win" games exist now. In general, I recommend removing the crafting time idea considering it takes time to gather resources to make most things in the first place. However, I have seen some game play and can see the potential. It does look beautiful with the block design, as well as the tiered crafting and recipe discovery system adding a twist to your typical crafting systems. The mobs having their own unique shapes and even having a night time counterpart is very pleasing to see despite probable adjustments needed. Once I can actually get some hands-on time, I might edit this review or post a better one, but for now, until the connection issues get settled or an offline mode is added for those who struggle with connection, I give it a thumbs down.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I applaud anyone trying to do what Minecraft does only differently -- Minecraft is far from perfect, and at this point Mojang/Microsoft has made so much money off the status quo that it is unlikely we are going to see great strides in the genre from them.  We need developers willing to retread the same ground and try different paths if we are going to see better games in the genre.But that being said, Minecraft is very, very good.  The bar can be vaulted, but it is set high.  And Creativerse makes some very basic errors in its early game that are going to relegate it to the dustbin of time if they are not fixed.  I don't usually write "first-person experience" reviews, but I think this will speak to fans of the genre.First thing I noticed is that even the starter recipes require many types of raw materials.  Forget about processed materials -- even turning wood into planks requires a device I would call "second tier."  I was fortunate, I had spawned into a region that was resource rich.  I can't imagine trying to play this game after spawning into an unfriendly biome (assuming they exist -- maybe you always spawn into dense forest?).  After some gathering I crafted up a wooden sword (three raw materials) and a wood power cell (four raw materials; used for mining stone) and struck out to find a cliff to dig a shelter into.What I discovered next was that the stone layer is extremely thin.  Maybe ten blocks from dirt to "bedrock" which required a stone power cell (five raw materials) to mine.  A stone power cell requires coal.  I wasn't lucky enough to find coal in the vicinity of my shelter so I made some more moss torches and went looking for a nearby cave.  Upon finding one I discovered that while a moss torch is sufficient to light a 3x3x3 room, it really only has a functional radius of 2 blocks out in the open.  That's not a lot of light.  I should have known, considering they only required two separate raw materials to manufacture.  Still, I figured there had to be a lot of coal not far beneath the surface and descended.  I could hear a monster, but I cowboyed up and kept going anyway.  I was still in the dirt layer, and was confident I wasn't deep enough to encounter anything truly dangerous.Boy was I wrong.Something green and  vaguely bipedal with about a dozen eyes surged up out of the darkness right in front of my face.  I defended myself with my wooden sword, and managed to get in about 20 good hits before it did me in with its blinding flashbulb and slam attacks.  That was it for me.  I quit to menu and exited the game.I don't want to be unfair -- I realize this game is free, and in early access besides -- but the incredibly high production quality throughout suggests that the developer is not an amateur, and yet the game balance leaves a lot to be desired.  The crafting system in this game is very complicated and interdependent, and therefore early game success feels like it is dependent more on luck than it should be.  To get A I need B, but if B isn't readily available I need C to go looking for it and C requires A.  That's a tough pill to swallow.  It is nice that the game abandons Minecraft's crafting grid -- while a clever way to get more mileage out of fewer materials, the grid can be very tedious and is ultimately unnecessary, as both the XBox Live and Pocket editions of the game have shown.  All things considered, though, I'm not sure the dozen kinds of raw materials required for first tier crafting in Creativerse is really a viable alternative.Combat is my least favorite part of any survival game -- I feel like most of them are better without it.  But even considering my bias, an enemy I can encounter during the day in the dirt layer should not require more than 20 hits with a crafted weapon to defeat!So, ultimately, no, I can't recommend this game, despite its price and despite its early access status.  I hope to see it improve, but right now the early game does not inspire confidence enough to warrant toughing it out to see the late game.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								At the current time, I feel that the developers have really started to simply let go and lose commitment to this game. When I first played it, I did a let's try miniseries on my youtube channel of it. At the time the devs were clearly very commited and knew exactly where they were going to take this game. I loved it and in the end told my viewers that I highly recommended it. But after around 4 months hiatus, I returned ti the game for yet another video, this time to "Revisit" the game and re-review it. And to my dismay, dissapointment, and slight annoyance, it made me realize just how far things have fallen for this game. A game that had immense potential, especially with such once-commited devs, that actually truly listened to the community have let go. And it seems those that are still at least half-commited are lost and split on the direction they want to take it. The game also still lacks a creative mode which is easily my biggest peeve with this game. It actually does make me a bit maddened. So all in all, my love for this game and excitement are all gone. Washed straight out of me. However I know there is still great potential for this game if the devs get back to where they were priorly in the beginning, back to be energized, excited, commited, and community oriented. Knowing the exact direction they wish to take it. So for the time being, it's honestly a "I'll leave it up to you to decide" notion rather than a don't/do recommend sequence from me. And that's my actual true stance on the game currently. But since I had to choose yes or no on recommending it in order to post this, it's easily a no.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								(Updated March 18th 2017)Creativerse is a 3D-block based sandbox game like Minecraft, which is a successor of Infiniminer by Zachtronics. However Creativerse is not a simplified MC-clone.* first of all; Creativerse is an online-game and does not provide an offline-version, it's designed for easy multiplayer access and shared experiences * still each player receives at least one gameworld for themselves where they can set world options to their likings and can protect their world/s with a password to play solo or only with close friends there* official public servers, player-moderated public servers and adventure instances are available for everyone additionally to that, and players can also claim areas on many gameworlds where specific protective claim options can be set* the game is easy to understand for beginners so they won't have to rely on Wikis. A tutorial and tooltips provide sufficient help, plus all common crafting recipes can be viewed in the crafting menu greyed out right from the start together with their unlocking requirements* gameworlds are not procedurally generated, but based on 4 preset template worlds of 10,240 x 10,240 x 256 blocks in size each, divided into 26x26 (676) areas with up to 43,264 possible player claims each* all currently created gameworlds feature 10+ surface biomes plus 4 different looking underground layers, each with their own biome-specific denizens* on all worlds 16 types of imaginative mobs can be found in up to 42 variants with different behaviour and specific attacks/defensive moves* all creatures can be either killed or tamed and can then become lifestock to be harvested from, after being fed and cleaned, and they can be dressed with a few accessories too* "Boss mobs" exist too, however only 2 for now, one has to be summoned by building* nearly all natural blocks (ca. 70 types) that the worlds are made of can be harvested and then placed again for building porposes, plus ca. 130 different looking types of crafted cubic building-blocks, ca. 30 roofs/slopes, ca. 16 slabs  and 20 stairs * nearly all blocks and placable items can be rotated into all 6 directions* 7 existent liquids with specific attributes can be collected, used for crafting and/or cooking and can also be placed into the world * crafting is a core-feature of the game, the gaming progress relies on unlocking the most important crafting recipes by collecting materials and crafting requirements as listed in the crafting menu. Up to 5 crafting recipes with their unlocking requirements or with their required ingredients can be tracked onscreen (like a shopping list)* players can hunt for randomly spawning treasure chests that sometimes contain rare collectible crafting recipes. Some crafting recipes for unique looking blocks can only be bought in the store* some more additional seasonal recipes and findings usually appear around halloween and christmas for up to 1 month each * players can create artificial biomes to make biome-specific creatures and treasure chests spawn. Even artificial biomes can feature the same gameplay-relevant environmental effects that natural biomes would have, like freezing cold, burning heat or poisoning corruption * currently 6 swords and 5 armor sets (helmets are WIP) help players to win and survive fights, plus 9 types of explosives can be thrown at adversaries (4 of which will affect the environment too in different ways), as well as rimecones and snowballs * 4 types of TNT can destroy the environment (however player claims and world settings can protect player property from being harmed), 3 types of excavators help with clearing larger areas (7x7x7) and will save half of the blocks they remove* only one harvesting/mining tool is required in Creativerse, and many items can be crafted on the fly without requiring any crafting stations * player characters can now be customized to a certain degree* after defeat/character death all the stuff that drops can be retrieved again by following the compass* teleporters can be crafted and placed in large amounts, also a "home-teleporter"* Creativerse has an area-based RPG-like mapping function too (no crafting required)* 4 types of crops and 3 types of trees can be grown, 36 types of food can be cooked, additional to edible mushrooms and a bunch of potions that provide different effects * adventures are a new feature that can be used by everyone to create instances of their worlds and let other players experience intresting builds, parcours, puzzles and/or stories there* players can use devices like switches, pressure plates, sensors and number pads to wire doors, trap doors, lights, beacons, fans (can be used together with ladders or ice slopes to create railways or "roller coasters"), campfires/pit fires, loot spawners and mob spawners from anywhere in the world - for protection, to build traps and to create adventures * players can craft up to 12 different types of storage containers, 4 beds, 10 tables, 9 chairs, 17 doors/gates + 3 trap doors, 9 windows, 4 types of fences (that can hold back creatures even if only 1 block in height), 5 inscribable signs and 2 types of climbable ladders too* several customizable blueprints of preset buildings are available for free to help with building large structures together with friends. Block kits containing all the suggested standard blocks necessary for specific blueprints can be bought in the store * there is a day-night-cycle that can be influenced by using beds* as for weather, there is either clear or foggy for now* the game usually uses first person view. Third person view is enabled while flying the glider, sitting on chairs or can optionally be switched to only while standing still * sleeping/resting or eating is not necessary for player-characters' survival, however cooked food (no decay) offers boosts, can negate falling damage, can make toons immune to cold, poison or corruption, or can even turn damage into healing* trading between players can be done by dropping player bags or by setting specific permission levels for storage containers for certain player types to use* healing of other player characters is not possible, but characters can heal themselves by consuming mushrooms, health potions or healing food, or else by standing in/close to mineral water or a healing beacon (that can also purify corruption btw.)* the background story consists only of hints on notes and data chips found in treasure chests* tons of features are still in the pipeline, like modding, a creative/creation mode, NPCs, villages, liquid transportation, railways and much much more, as the developers have hinted at on the forums where they actively participate The "Pro" update has been a bone of contention and really might not be the best possible solution, however it was a necessary attempt to finance the further game development after Playful had decided to make the basic Creativerse game free to play so it will be easily accessible for all kinds of players, including younger audience and people who have to economize.* while free players have one world of their own, the "Pro" upgrade allows players to create many more worlds of their own where they can define more world options than free players can, plus they get a glider and a flashlight, 2 free claims on each gameworld, 20 additional inventory slots and double stamina* early backers and everyone who has ever spent money in the store of Creativerse before August 2nd 2016 have automatically been promoted to the "Pro"-status with release/update R33 and have kept all their old worlds.* even players who have played for free up to August 2nd 2016 and have not ever spent any money for Creativerse have kept their old worlds - and are additionally to that provided with one new world where they will find themselves after returning to the game for the first time.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								As of right now, this gets a thumb down from me.Now, before I go into why, bear in mind the game is FREE TO PLAY. Try the game yourself, becuase the flaws I list may not be flaws that you have an issue with.So, first of all, the game is Increadibly smooth. The mechanics are very smooth and well thought out.Sadly though,  you Burn through gear, especially compared to minecraft, because instead of using just one or two blocks to "mine" you end up having to use your mining tool to mine EVERY BLOCK in that entire section (not counting extractors mind). So as an example, I was having to craft a new mining tool every time I went down, and it got to the point I carried two or three on me, simply because it stopped being cost effective to do so. Plus you have to hunt down multiple resources to craft set things. Enemies do respawn, but it was a frustrating and annoying experience for me, not an enjoyable one. I almost feel the game devs created this to be played with multiple people, so the drain on gear isn't as bad as it is with one player. However, since I WAS playing one player.......the grind was real.And honestly, that ONE fact destroyed the game for me. For me, I love exploring, just running around, and checking stuff out, but....sadly there's not a ton of content here. On top of that, this game as been around since August of 2014. Now, I have not been a part of the DEV team, nor have I really played through or been a part of the updates, but the fact that there's not a whole lot of different areas/content (like, expansive worlds I mean), a LOT of grinding, and the cash shop selling blocks, I sorta get the feeling that the Dev team put most of its work into the game fluidity and mechanics, which are fantasitc. But it suffers in other areas.So for me, personally, while it does have good points, the areas it suffers are reasons why I play games. Exploration, crafting, combat, but mostly exploring. So when grinding is the focus, the game suffers for me.As I said though, the game is completely free to play, and the "pro" version costs 20 bucks. If you like the game yourself, buy it to support the developers.Edit: Good to see people are still marking reviews down they disagree with, regardless if it was actually helpful or not

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Meh. This game is not bad, but most certainly NOT the worst Minecraft clone ever at least. Still though, I don't recommend this game under my point of view with some valid reasons explained.Pros:+Tone down version of Minecraft with relaxing music.+Functions like Minecraft (digging for stuff, crafting, fighting monsters, etc.).+An atypical Minecraft clone.+Customizable characters.+Graphics are average, plays smoothly  at least on a potato or a toaster.Cons:-An in-game cash shop for P2W aspects.-Extractors for things to be built takes up to 5 minutes or more. -Movement system is not good, jumping feels like there's low gravity in space.-Combat system is also bad, monsters have a longer range, and there are no effective ranged weapons.-Building and exploring are probably the main aspects of this game mostly. Come on, a lot of crafting involved? In the end, I would rather play Minecraft than this game. Minecraft already has its own aspects that are probably better than Creativerse.Now listen. I can see this game going to become better at least in the future, but we will have to wait and see if that will happen, since this game is in Early Access. I might come back and try this game again, so be aware of this. My review might be deleted or edited for a different opinion.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I haven't delved too deep (YET) into Creativerse, but what time I've spent in it (a few months ago as of this review, I'm sure there's all sorts of new stuff!) has been quite fun. Sure, it's another Minecraft type game, but so what? That's a good thing. The way things function however, make the game play quite different than minecraft even early on, and from what I could tell it was only going to get more divergent on its own path. One thing I can tell up front is this is more of an exploration based/combat game in terms of your delving down below ground. Sure, there are critters in minecraft, but no one really worries about any of the minecraft creatures. This game has things that will EAT YOU AND SPIT OUT YOUR EYES TO MAKE SOUP FOR LEFTOVERS ON THURSDAY. Anyways, I strongly recommend this game if you like building/open world/exploration minecraft type games, enough that I suggest you pay for it despite it eventually going free to play upon release. Support the devs for their quality, hard work, and have fun building and exploring!

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								This *was* a good game until they not only went Pay to Play, but are also heading towards Pay to Win. I normally like to give pros and cons for the games I review, however this game no longer deserves it. Instead, let's see just what caused me to hate it so much so suddenly. It was free to play with stuff you could buy from the store for coins and real money. That's fine. It's an Early Access game. That's fine. It's vaguely a Minecraft clone. That's fine. What's NOT fine is springing this "DLC" on us. Extra inventory space? Extra items? Are you sh!^^ing me?! Aside from that, the "DLC" basically says, "Gee, you're really enjoying our game, huh? Here, let me take about 90% of its pieces out of your toy box and demand your lunch money to get them back." Doesn't seem very fair does it? It's borderline Bully Tactics really. So because this "company" decided to pull this stunt, this game has immediately fallen out of the good light I saw it in before, and likely will never return unless this P2P/P2W BS is corrected. 0/10. Correct your sins, or forever burn in Gaming Hell, Playful Corporation.
