content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game, even without getting Pro, because you can still do everything. It has a good system for minig and crafting which is what you'll spend your time doing; the mining is a bit different due to the higher quality ores having to be mined with a device that is timed. It kind of wraps around a single block and works on that one ore while you go explore other things or craft. Crafting is similar to most of the systems already in use by other games of this type; gather, refine, and craft. You also use a type of gauntlet that you upgrade to gather ores that are deeper within the crust of the game world.You can buy plots of land with resources and you control what happens on the land. This is nice so that others don't come along and destroy what you have made. You can make it possible for others to warp to your specified location and you decide who can modify your area if you want a friends help.The monsters are basic at this point and so are the weapons you use; by basic I mean a small variety, limited actions, and predicable. The weapons you get are just the same melee weapon upgraded over and over. I really just want a ranged weapon.. upgrading the same weapon over and over is... meh I do like the game other than that though.

								When I first played this game, I expected a Minecraft clone but that is not the case. Creativerse is enjoyable and it allows you to create impressive builds or simply waste a few minutes (or hours in my case) of the day. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let's not beat around the bush...Creativerse (C) is obviously inspired by Minecraft (M).  This review will compare the two games assuming that you are already familiar with M.  Although I haven't played C nearly as much as I've played M, I wanted to get my initial impressions written down.  I will update this review as I continue to play C.To be clear, I RECOMMEND the Free-to-Play version.  I DO NOT recommend the $20 Pro version at this time.PROS+ Improved art style makes the world much more attractive and vibrant+ Brilliant crafting system makes M's feel ancient, frustrating and obsolete+ Excellent quest, hint, mapping, and item-tracking system is very modern and fun+ Incredible Blueprint system makes building advanced structures a breeze+ Free-to-Play allows you to see almost everything without paying a dimeCONS- Mining is way too convoluted; must repeatedly craft harvesters for basics like coal and iron- Harvesting blocks takes way too long and can only be done ONE block at a time- Mobs, while unique, are bizarre and unintuitive (WHAT drops X item again?)- Can get confusing when transferring items between inventory, quickbar, and workshop/forge UI- Free-to-Play model (with non-refundable DLC "unlock" and microtransactions) seems greedy- Still feels shallow when compared to M (still in Early Access, however)

Multiplayer is considerably better than single player imo: luckily, if you do have a single player world, friends can join easily as worlds are hosted externally. I look forward to the future of Creativerse.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great game, even without getting Pro, because you can still do everything. It has a good system for minig and crafting which is what you'll spend your time doing; the mining is a bit different due to the higher quality ores having to be mined with a device that is timed. It kind of wraps around a single block and works on that one ore while you go explore other things or craft. Crafting is similar to most of the systems already in use by other games of this type; gather, refine, and craft. You also use a type of gauntlet that you upgrade to gather ores that are deeper within the crust of the game world.You can buy plots of land with resources and you control what happens on the land. This is nice so that others don't come along and destroy what you have made. You can make it possible for others to warp to your specified location and you decide who can modify your area if you want a friends help.The monsters are basic at this point and so are the weapons you use; by basic I mean a small variety, limited actions, and predicable. The weapons you get are just the same melee weapon upgraded over and over. I really just want a ranged weapon.. upgrading the same weapon over and over is... meh I do like the game other than that though.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll open with a bold statement: This game will probably be the Minecraft killer, but only if the developers allow the community to create content akin to the Minecraft community's. That's what separates the men from the boys in this genre, nowadays. The developers have done a great job taking what's good about the big sandbox games and mashing them into one. There's very obvious and heavy inspiration coming in from Terraria, but I feel like it's done better simply on merit of the fact that this type of game should be 3D. The character models are laughably bad, and it would be really nice if they'd add in an option to have the magic mining hand from the videos instead of the unsightly and cartoonish Hulk hand that we get in game. Monsters spawn way too frequently - I've had instances of six or seven of the same monster spawning all around me. It really makes me glad there isn't a creeper knockoff in this game, or else everything you try to accomplish would be blown apart as soon as night falls. Combat is atrocious and completely dominated by tossing bombs. I don't necessarily mind this, but the complexity and costliness of the sword recipes implied I'd be getting at least some use out of them. Armor is equally useless, partially because it does a poor job of preserving your health, but also partially because as I just mentioned, becoming a mad bomber is infinitely more effective. What you need to craft bombs comes from the easiest of enemies, so honestly, it almost feels like the devs just wanted to give you a sword just strong enough to one-shot passive mobs so that you can craft bombs to deal with their stronger, aggressive counterparts. Mining and building are fine, but somehow they feel... clunky is the only word I can think to describe it. Maybe it's because of how fast your base walking speed is, but it feels like you're constantly outpacing yourself both while mining and building, and it doesn't have the smooth, meticulous satisfaction factor that Minecraft has. Useful ores are extremely scarce, and the strange system of having to build an extractor to mine ore vs just taking it like any other block, while more realistic, really interrupts the flow. We've already accepted "you have a magic gauntlet that teleports dirt, rocks, and virtually everything else to hammerspace", there's no need to put the strange emphasis on realistic handling of raw materials. Possibly the best thing ever put into a game of this genre, however, are the excavators, which act like primed charges ready to literally take a chunk out of whatever you're near. Combined with the nifty rotation feature, you can landscape and mine at unmatched efficiency. Materials in general is another thing that really throws me off about Creativerse. The amount of stuff you can pick up is nearing infinite shelf tier. There's nothing wrong with variety, but past a certain point, it becomes too much. Not only can you mine a boatload of stuff, but everything seems to have a use. In theory, this is great - the player never feels like they're wasting time shoveling dirt or stone while trying to get to something important, but in practice, it makes crafting things a chore. Some recipes, like the Lumite mining gauntlet, ask for ridiculous ingredients (cactus flower, in this case), as if the developers just shoehorned some of this stuff into usefulness instead of just letting it be. Not only that, but there's so much in-between. Mined some diamond, now I have to go smelt this diamond into a diamond bar (let's not get into how silly that is), and for most recipes that use damond, I have to go process it even further. This holds true for almost every material in the game, and it really drags the experience through the mud. I'd feel more compelled to mine and craft and build if my inventory weren't constantly filled with situationally useful items and my house didn't have to be made of chests to accomdate everything. The current system turns you into a packrat, as until you've put 400 hours into the game and memorized every possible recipe, you feel like everything you pick up must have a use, and to reiterate a previous point, it probably does. The weirdest part of it all is how massive your inventory actually is and yet, it still ends up getting filled with garbage. Within minutes of a routine excursion, you'll find that three to five slots of your inventory is taken up with one or two blocks of unique materials that are functionally identical to one another. As it stands, there's just no real solution for this. There's just too much stuff in the game.Lastly, the world itself is interesting enough. There's a good spread of biome specific mobs, and a reasonable assortment of biomes. The fact that the temperature of the area affects blocks as well as the player is a nice touch, it shows an attention to detail that you normally just can't get from most games. The temperature of the area affecting the player would normally be a huge turn off for me, but Creativerse handles it nicely. The extra Corruption layer at the center of the world is a nice surprise, with a sort of "last frontier" feel. In the future, I'd love to see more done with it, to give players a few more reasons to visit other than "this is where you find the 'best' mineral".Simply put, Creativerse offers a lot, especially considering that it's free. It has some kinks and bugs to work out, some balancing to address, and the other pitfalls that come with games that are still firmly in beta, but it has potential. If you're call my opening statement, I believe it has a lot of potential, but that remains to be seen.

Posted: December 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								+Great progression system+Visual appeal+FREE+Music is fantastic.+Claim your ground, assign players to help you build amazing things while no one else can grief you there.+Teleportation to your Home, Friends place, or even a strangers if they allow you!-Only 1 personal world means you are stuck with what you get, you can reset it but never get a true "new" World without paying.-Pro can be considered pay to win.-Global Chat spam by killing creatures or creating items.Overall not just a dime a dozen minecraft clone. Fun to play alone or with others. Plenty of adventure to be had. Highly recommended.

								Fun game with lots of potential. I only just started checking it out and haven't gotten to far but one issue keeps bothering me. FIX THE FULLSCREEN.... Maybe it is just me but when I am fighting fullscreen the screen suddenly reverts to windowed mode and as I click to attack it starts dragging the window around... This keeps happening pretty much every time I fight making it really hard if not impossible to kill anything that fights back much.I have never had this happen with any other games so I assume it is something about the fullscreen mode.
